item.title: By: velda
item.dc:creator: velda
item.description:
The Russians actually did something very similar to what you're proposing. When I was there in 1996, I could buy a snickers bar for about 5,000 rubles. I could buy a piece of "Love Is" gum for 200-300 rubles, depending on the day. Rubles were the paper money, by the way. I don't think I ever saw a one-ruble bill. The exchange rate was around 5000-6000 rubles per dollar, again, depending on the day. So even carrying 100 ruble bills was akin to carrying pennies.
Only children kept coins: they had absolutely no economic value, but they looked neat in jars, and they were great for play. A few of the children I knew well had jars and jars of coins: not only tiny kopeks (which were worth .01 rubles) and other sub-ruble denominations, but 5, 10, and 50 ruble coins, too. And then I think in 1997 or 1998, Russia decided to do just what you've hinted at here: they dropped the zeros, made new bills, and brought the coins back into regular circulation.
Even then, the ruble didn't really stabilize, but I can only imagine what fun my little friends had with their coin-jars! So now my kids and I keep jars of pennies, just in case.
